text: Shared bottle. Hazy straw pour toward copper with off-white head. Nose was earthy Munich malt, nuts, caramel. Earthy flavor, somewhat nutty, caramelly, with a smooth finish.

On tap at the Tea Merchant Canary Wharf. Clear gold lasting white head. Marzen malty aroma. I mean its a pretty authentic pale marzen. Hoppy finish. Yep ok. Doesnt go anywhere. Fine if a little harsh.

Keg at Three Johns, 04/10/16.
Clear golden with a decent off white covering.
Nose is pale malts, straw, grains, caramel.
Taste comprises bready malts, caramel, light lemon drizzle, toasted grains, corn.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Clean and crisp easy drinking number - decent.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 4th October 2016The 3 Johns. Keg. Bright clear gold beer, small white head. Palate is smooth and semi dry, nice fine crispness. Clean and sweetish pale malts. Touch of cream. Mild nutty vibe, German style. Very mild orange citrus and a touch of orange peel. Light finish. Clean and drinkable.

Small bottle from a local liquor store. Im sorry, I dont get what the fuss is about. Its pleasant and drinkable, but not very interesting. Good for style maybe. I guess I dont appreciate the style. 3.3

Tap pours at Stag & Lion and 12oz bottles at home. Clear golden pour with great foam. Nose is honey, fresh bread. Pretty neutral. Taste is slightly papery, mild salt, fairly dry for style, no alcohol warming, no sticky caramel. It goes in a different direction than what Im used to for this style, and it probably better off for it.
355ml bottle at Beer Station, Xiamen. Pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma of malt. Sticky sweetness. Quite enjoyable.

355ml bottle into weizen glass. Sweet sweet bready malt nose, hints of butterscotch and vanilla. Slightly hazy amber beer with steady stream of fine bubbles. Slight zing in the mouth, full-bodied. Finish is oily, caramel and alcohol. There is a slight bitterness at the end but doesnt really balance the cloying alcohol chewiness. Salright.

Aus der Flasche vom Händler des Vertrauens. Goldfarben im Glas mit low carbonisation und schnell verschwindenen Schaum. Was dann bleibt ist eine liebliche Malzigkeit. Sonst nix. Keine Chance gegen die bayrischen Originale.

On tap at The Mayor of Old Town. Clear golden appearance with a lingering, lacy white head. Aroma of toasted Munich malts and light hops (earthy, spicy, herbal). Similar flavor, smooth and malty with a light to mild hop bitterness. Crisp mouth feel with ample carbonation. An easy drinker overall.

From the bottle to pour is clear and caramel colored, the aroma is mild almost like water but my wife is picking up more notes than I am so Im sure its good, the taste was immediately caramel theres a nice sweet hit to the back end of the throat, and the finish is almost like caramelize sugar, that would make this sound like a very sweet beer but this isnt this is very good balanced Oktoberfest

12 oz bottle from notes. Pours a deep amber/copper color with a small off white head that faded into a film. The aroma and flavor have toasted bready malts, caramel, some general fruitiness, grass, lager notes, pretty much a basic, clean Oktoberfest.
Smooth, full-bodied Oktoberfest with a nice caramel aroma and sweet, malty finish. I look forward to SN trying to find a comparable partner and equally good product this fall.

From bottle in dimpled mug. Pours clear bronze with one-finger head and aroma of dough with a hint of cloves. Malty sweetness with a bit of spice on the palate. I was a little late cracking into this so it was probably past its prime.

Cor dourada e um pouco brilhante com algum perlage; espuma branca de baixas formação e persistência, sem lacing.
Aroma maltado de pão doce.
Sabor de início maltado com um final picante e de amargor marcante mas comportado; retrogosto maltado bem leve.
Corpo médio e media carbonatação.

From notes (Oct. 2015). An excellent Oktoberfest that makes the most of this underappreciated style. Extremely clean fermentation leaves the malt sweetness to come through and dominate. Some nuttiness comes through, and a little bit of noble hop flavor. Killer.

12 ounce bottle from hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. Clear cinnamon in color. An almost white one finger head. Steady carbonation floating up. The aroma is kind of dank and damp. Earthy. First sip brings spices and earth. Under that lurks spicy bitterness. Mid glass a little tangerine emerges. And then sugar. The style can be less than exciting but this one rises above most. Plenty of nice flavors to enjoy.

Share with Strykzone on Facebook Chat, Pours clear dark gold with a creamy white head. Good lacing. Nose of spice. Medium body. Favor is malty with spicy hops and fruit. Tangerine I would say. Lots of earth in the taste and in the bitter finish. Aroma of mildly spicy bread. Med body or nearly. Flavor is mildly spicy
Bottle. Poured a clear orange copper color with a small white head. Aroma was crisp lager notes, sweet grain notes. Flavor was sweet grains, crisp notes. Light earthy notes. Decent.
Bottle. Clear bright golden amber pour, with a white head. Bready, cereal, mild caramel, glue, and grass. Ok, not very interesting.

Poured into a perfect pint.

3.5 A: Clear dark yellow color. One and a half fingers of frothy white head. Retention is about average and a half finger of lacing is left.

4.0 S: Crackery and grainy malts. Caramel, grassy hops. Pumpernickel bread. Fierce lager yeast. 

4.0 T: Plenty of toastiness with mineral lager yeast. Crackery, bready, grainy. Mild sweetness with focus on caramel. Grassy and lightly earthy hops.

4.5 M: Lighter medium body with a bit of viscosity in there. Good moderate carbonation. Pleasantly creamy and super smooth. Perfect for the style here.

4.0 D: Really freaking tasty.

★ 617 characters


DavoleBomb, Sep 17, 2015
Amber color. This beer has some cereal character, but also some glue in the aroma. Clean. But not very interesting.
Bottle - Sweet grains and caramel. Clear copper with a bit of a beige head. Light grains and caramel. Solid Oktoberfest.

12 oz. bottle, pours a hazy dull bronze with a small white head. Aroma brings out bready malts, some corn and light toasty notes. Flavour is along the same lines, with corn, bready malt and toasted malt. Simple, but clean and decently balanced. A properly constructed marzen.

Clear golden color with white head. Aroma has classic sweet malt and bread crust. Taste starts also malty, grainy, with a bit of honey sweetness and bread crust. Some hops in the background give a slight bitterness on the finish. Medium body with crisp carbonation. Really well made, classic marzen style beer. Not bad but its a style I am not very fond of.
(bottle) clear, bright light amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of stewed fruit, jam; creamy palate; balanced flavour with a long, very light bitter finish; well done

33cl bottle
orange color
aroma of caramel and malty, lightly toasty
flavor herbal

355 ml bottle from BeerLovers, bottled 09/02/15.
Amber, clear body, wit a quite small, fluffy, a bit lacing, light beige head.
Aroma of grains, flowers, bread, citrus, some grass.
Tastes of bread, flowers, citrus, grass, some herbs, honey, some biscuit.
Medium, a bit oily mouthfeel, with an average carbonation.
Finishes medium bitter, floral, bready, a bit zesty, a bit herbal, also a bit sweet.

Nice one. Not my favourite style example, but quaffable, with nice bready and floral notes. I would prefer a bit more biscuity body though, as it isnt very hoppy.

Bottle: two labels but not information about the hops, malts and drink temperature
Golden colour, clear liquid, strong fizzy, moderate bitter, short head, no smell of anything,
(I have a 0.33l bottle with batch PKGD 09/02/15 0754 on the label but on the bottle is 090215M0740)

Bottle: Golden, lively csrbonation, small and slowly collapsing loose white head; moderate sweet pale-malty nose, some dust detectable, some impressions of honey, too; moderate sweet flavour with a bitterness, that is barely detectable; medium bodied, soft; hardly lingering clean sweet-malty finish with a delicate bitterness in the aftertaste. Nothing wrong with it, but completely overrated. Lacks a decent hoppy counterpart

Bottle. Bright amber color with ivory foam. Herbal, lagered caramel, spicy aromas. Medium bodied. Lagered spicy caramel lightly sweet flavors with some subtle herbal hoppage, and bready maltage----good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 0.355 l bottle from Biermuda, bottled in September 2015. Clear, golden yellow with a medium large, frothy, slowly diminishing, white head. Sweetish-malty, slightly floral aroma of biscuits, honey and caramel. Sweetish-malty, slightly floral taste of biscuits, honey, some vanilla and caramel, followed by a short, slightly bitter, minimally grassy finish. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel, average carbonation. Very nice, totally round and harmonic with deep, intense malt flavours.
Aroma is a nice sweet malt. Taste is nicely balanced with some bitterness. Overall very solid.

Dark gold pour with a one finger, off white head. Grainy nose with some floral and spicy hops, a hint of caramel and toast. Flavor is big on cereal, some oily grain, big floral hops, some spicy, a little biscuity malt and some floral hops. Light to medium body, creamy to juicy feel, light carbonation. Good stuff overall, a little too floral and fruity for my taste in the style.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear, bright copper with a small, barely off-white head that settles into a ring and a tiny island of film. Bright, vivid, and totally translucent. Notes of spiced cracker, hay, toast, caramel, grass, and a hint of fruit. Has kind of a horse stable note to it. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a mouthfeel that teeters on the edge of smooth and musty. Not a malt-forward example of the style; the notes are there but its pretty sharp and clean.

Aroma: bread and grain malts, light caramel. Appearance: clear gold, medium, frothy, white head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: grain malts continue, caramel, light toasted notes, bread, touch of floral hops, light floral hops coming up towards the finish. Overall: very sweet and malty Maerzen, not bad, fairly subtle complexity in both aroma and palate. Pint at The Fine Line, Canary Wharf.
Many thanks for this beer to Erzengel. Pours a deep golden color. The aroma has notes of malt, straw and grain. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of bread

Draft, TD Bank Garden, Boston. Served in a 12 oz. plastic cup. (no mug available) The color looks orange with some lasting white foam for head. Aroma is old biscuits, mild toffee and traces of a grassy hop. 
Backbone of the beer is traditional for the style: baked bread, toffee malts, and light hints of yeast in the finish. Body is the lighter side of medium with balanced hops and malt. Smooth mouthfeel. Hits the mark for the style, easy to drink without any type of flaws or issues. If you like the style you will enjoy a sample of this.

On tap at Earth. Pours a clear orange amber with a thin white head. Crisp with a sweet grain character and a vague hint of smoke, fruit, and crackers. Medium bodied, malty, sweet, floral malt. Sweet malt into the finish. Lingering toast. Clean and easy drinking.
Golden klar, wenig Schaum, typisch malzig in der Nase, relativ massig im antrunk, schöner Malzkörper, im Abgang schönes Aroma, das Lust zum weitertrinken macht
Klares dunkel goldenes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch kräftig malzig, leicht hopfig. Geschmack dezent hopfig, süß malzig, karamellig.

The beer starts malty and smooth. Very soft and round, nice malt character with a full and easy to drink body. Round and smooth, very soft, The malt has roasty hints, caramel, not too sweet. Nice and full with a caramelly, malty smooth long lasting aftertaste. Great!

(bottle, 2015 Riegele collab. ed., 35.5cl) Clear, golden colour with a mid-sized and slightly off-white foamy head. Bready and delicately toasted malty aroma with notes of caramel, oak honey, backed by herbal hops. Moderately sweetand slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a modest carbonation. Slightly toasted malty and bready base with a whiff of herbal and slightly peppery hops; sweet-bitter malt-accented finish with rounded herbal hops. A decent brew, but I expected something more sophisticated, especially after I´ve had a Schönramer Festbier just before. 07.XII.15

Sierra Nevadas latest version of Oktoberfest is a homage to the German brewing style. Golden medium bodied O-Fest with soft nose, malt body and slight lemon sweetness and subtle hop bite. Makes a great Thanksgiving beer.

A 12 fl oz bottle packaged on 17th August 2015 and poured into a Duvel tulip glass. It poured a clear golden orange colour with a one and a half finger slightly off white coloured head that had pretty good retention. Aromas were of toasty bread with honey and apple with a hint of caramel. Generally its the sweet aroma. Taste leans on the sweet side and definitely malty and bready with some grain plus hints of caramel and toffee. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Overall, this was decent and easy to drink but nothing exceptional, though it is worth a try. Its a one time brew, but even if I could buy it again, Im not sure I would.
From a bottle. Looks great and lives up to it, quite tasty with lots of big flavours, very good work.

Bottle from Beer Cartel 261115. Nice and malty with some toffee in the finish. Looks goods, smells good and tastes good, what more can you ask for in a beer. Well packaged also in typical Sierra Nevada style.

355 ml bottle. Pours a clear amber-gold with a sudsy but lasting white head and lively carbonation. Aromas of crackers, fresh apple, flowers and cut grass. Taste is light citrus up front, followed by a crisp and spicy hop note. Clean finish as expected. Not my favourite style but I like what this is doing.
Bottle. Pours a light amber color with small white head and lively carbonation. Aroma is mostly caramel malt with some cereal notes. Malty and sweet. Light bodied. I enjoyed this.

Poured from bottle. Was in back of fridge so very cold. Sweet malt aroma. Gold Amber with hardly any head. Gotta let this warm up a bit. Malt flavor with more lager hops than the usual fest beer - nice. Black pepper notes. Good stuff.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottle.Nice looking amber pour with a good sized head. Malty, maple-syrupy nose. Malt-driven lager flavors as expected, a somewhat strong minerally bitterness from the hops. Pretty decent, but far from a favorite for me.
A quarter inch of foam sits atop the brew for the entire session. Sweet mellow and good. Mild, buttery finish. Nuanced, like many German brewers are known for.
Pours a clear amber with a slightly off white head. Aromas of, caramel, nuts and herbs. Taste the same with a little, bread and cereal flavors. Nice example of this lager.

355 ml bottle bought at CitySuper in New Town Plaza, Shatin.
Looks: Clear light amberless than one quarter finger head and residual soapy white foam which fades in 15 seconds; Fair good sticky lacing with active carbonation.

Aroma: Quite fragrant amber malt, with caramel, floral, honey, thin toffee, nutmeg, light lemon and light grass.

Taste: Close to medium sweet amber malt, with moderate roastyness, very strong caramel, toffee, light toast, barley grains, floral, light molasses, light bread, light spice, strong lemon, notable bitter hops and light grass.

Body: Mid to light body, slick palate.

Mouth Feel: Very good maltyness in a quite solid body. Strong Bock-like grainy roastyness with lots of caramel, toffee and light toast throughout. Good floral, very light sweetness, and booze is very well hidden. Slightly bready with good lemon to round. Very nice!

Hoppiness: Floral, honey, nutmeg, light lemon and light grass in nose, and stronger in taste; Bitterness is light but notable for a lasting, light astringent caramel malty finish.

After Taste: Fairly dry. Easy and light sweet to mouth.

Comments: This one has a very rich caramel aroma and taste, with some intriguing spices, light sweetness and neat hoppiness for a clean and enjoyable experience. Very likeable!

Bottle. This was a really good Oktoberfest beer. Amber-copper in color with a large head. Aroma had hints of roasted grains and caramel. Taste was caramel, roasted grains with a well balanced finish. Nice.
Bottle from Citysuper on IFC roof before dad's flight. Malty sweetness dominates with some earthy spicy hops up front. Not bad for this style.

BOTTLE. 2015. Pours a clear gold with small white head, good carb bubbles.. Herbal notes and citrus zest on the nose.. Malts are subtle from start to finish, yeastie pilsner vibe at back end, some honey.. Sourced cellarbrations @ capel
Drank from the bottle because hey, tailgating. If Id known how nice this was going to be I would have saved it for a proper glass. Light malty sweetness, fresh grain and a touch of lemon.

Btl pours a slightly hazy, bright golden color,big head with tight compact bubbles, lingers leaving rings of lace on glass. Light perfume,herbal and floral aromas with a hint of toast,again these aromas are very faint. Tastes of biscuits, minerals and a hint of spiciness. Light to medium body,soft smooth mouthfeel,perfect carbonation and a slightly dry finish. At first I felt this beer was boring. After I savored it for awhile it grew on me. It has a very clean and crisp flavor to it. I felt the flavor profile is complex. It is very smooth and easy to drink. I wish I would have tried this earlier in the season, I only was able to get one bottle. Definitely a solid brew!

From both bottle and on draft, pours a delightful rich golden bordering on copper with a good inch or so of firn white foam. Aroma is Munich malt toasty sweetness and the classic aromas of German hops, light lemony citrus, and hay. Taste is toasted grains, a touch of classic Munich sweetness that thankfully is not caramel or toffee, more like honey, balanced with a solid hop bite and the hint of lemoniness again. Medium bodied, gloriously drinkable (6 cases and counting!), and just the perfect lager for autumn.

Bottle from the fall sampler. Very light copper color. Bitterness from noble hops and a very light mineral quality that work well with this beer. Very early quality with some grass. Alcohol is present in the flavor a little bit it doesnt hurt the beer but is there a dry finish with some bread and grains. Surprisingly good.

Poured a clear dark amber colour with a one- to two-finger off-white foamy head that retained very well and laced very well. Carbonation high with lots of fine to coarse bubbles. Aroma of malt, not over-powering; no obvious hops. Taste is quite sweet (not as sweet as the recent Abbey Dubbel) with caramel tones; no real bitterness. Light body. Crisp with a sweet finish.

Bottle from Pacific Grove, CA Trader Joes. Translucent gold pour. Aroma is wet hay and apple. Flavor is slightly sweet, slightly bitter, and slightly tangy. Aftertaste is bitter. Body is light. Level of carbonation is medium to high. Not the most complex beer, but a well brewed beer with no off flavors.
Good Oktoberfest taste. Strong caramel and bread aroma and taste. It is enjoyable. Simple not much to say.
Kind of a general oktoberfest beer, light and golden body, light malt flavors against sweeter hop and yest profile. Too light overall.
Bottle. This is really a lovely beer. Heavily spiced version of an Oktoberfest. Easy to drink but with some flavor. Some brown sugar, clove.
From bottle at Red Knot, in a pilsner glass. Golden amber with large white head. Well crafted Marzen style beer, very enjoyable balanced hops taste.
Amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is a little sweet and somewhat nutty. Flavor is sweet, very malty with a full body. Very well balanced.

Pours clear medium gold with a thick white head. A lot lighter in color than I expected for an Octoberfest. Aroma of Malt, toffee, a hint of earth. Taste is sweet malt, caramel. Steady fine carbonation, nice mouth feel

5 on 5 for appearance. A towering plume of white is held proud aloft a vibrant, bright amber body. After an initial, sulphury, eggy fart wanes it reveals ample, dusty toasted malt and rich melanoidens with just a hint of Vienna malts adding a rusty element to it. Meaty, chunky malts on thee palate. Biscuity sweet with a good fare of fresh toasted bread, grain husks and granola. Finish has a light peppery note and noticeable alcohol with the sweetness tapering off. Body is medium and it shies away from becoming cloying even as it warms. The carbonation I had hoped would be slightly higher as it is quite soft - this is probably its only real flaw.This is a delicious otherwise and a true homage to the great, but now mostly absent, Oktoberfests of München. Impressed! (12fl.Oz, bottled 27/07/15, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)
On draft at the Allen Street Grill in State College. A traditional Oktoberfest with a bit more hop bite. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle into a dimple mug. Packaged on 8/7/2015.

Aroma - Bready with a faint noble hop character. 

Appearance - Lovely golden hue with a soapy white head. Sticky lacing for days.

Taste - Malt, malt, malt with a touch of toffee sweetness. Liquid bread in every way with an unparalleled balance for the style. Floral hops, with faint acidity, counter the fanastic bready mayhem. Biscuit and mild acidity linger on the palate. 

Palate - Medium bodied with extreme sessionability. Snappy carbonation. 

Overall - Rivals Ayinger of the best marzen. This is a supreme beer.

Bottle at Len. Clear, light orange, with a medium, fine head. Nice malt nose, light caramel, quite German actually. Slightly grass, with a bit of citrus. Sweet flavor, caramel and biscuits, full but clean. Decent stuff.

Pours a light orange color with a surprising peach aroma. Taste is light pumpkin, mixed with grainy malt. Typical European bitterness which is very evident in the aftertaste. A light flavored beer, easy drinking.

12 oz bottle. Bottled 8/13/15. (The Liquor Collection) Honolulu, HI.
Clear golden color with a small white head. 
Malt, citrus, mild hops, some sweetness and a touch of alcohol in the aroma. 
The flavor is sweet malt, mild hops, mild bitterness, sweetness and a hint of alcohol. A Märzen true to its origins but unfortunately hopelessly boring.

12oz bottle pours with a clear gold body that supports a full off white head of foam. The aroma offers up spicy Noble like hops that are a little herbal and grassy. Behind the hops lurks a pleasing maltiness that has a thin edge of biscuit malts to it. The taste starts with a nice bite of spicy hops that get just a touch earthy and faintly lime like. To midway the malts bubble to the surface to add a bit of depth and balance. The hops grow in bitterness into the finish. Pretty solid brew where the hops and malts play well together.

Six pack. Attractive beer with a nice strong aroma. Good head and rich, malty body. Malty (more Munich than Vienna) but not sweet thanks to the hops. The hops taste Gernan but seem to have a slight floral aspect to them, which is a bit strange. Still, a well-made Oktoberfest.

Pours a thin head on a clear straw body.
The aroma is initially caramel, then dry grains and leaves. 
The taste is nicely malt sweet, caramel and a little woody.
The texture is chewy.
Enjoyable.
Bottle. Amber beer with a nice cream head. Light spice and light caramel aroma. Spice and citrus flavor with caramel. Medium bodied. Spice and light grapefruit lingers with light earth and caramel.

From a fresh bottle, this interesting collaborative rendition pours a surprisingly faint clear amber appearance, lighter than usual for a marzen, almost seems like a halfway point between marzen and Helles. The aroma is distinctly German noble hops and grainy caramel malt. Taste likewise has grassy hops followed by a light malty taste with a sour earthy finish. Light bodied, smooth, and just a lighter beer overall, almost more fitting for the summer than the Fall. Good but not my personal favorite Oktoberfest bier.

Sauerkraut nose, obvious but not strong. Dried leaves and nuts also present. Crystal clear amber, medium head. Dried leaves, caramel, nuts, grass. Very slight fusel alcohol presence. Full body, moderate carbonation. I like the hop and malt bills, rich in complexity and body. Has some detractors, however.
Not much to way about this one.. Little aroma of hops. Clear yellow color like Apple juice. Taste of a stronger but balanced lager.

Pours a light golden color. Light cream colored head, about one finger. Little to no lacing.Aroma is light. Malty and sweet. Slightly hoppy. Toffee and maybe buttery. < p>Taste is very smooth. Sweet, and earthy hops balance well. It finishes a little bitter, and maybe a little peppery. Mouthfeel is astounding. So smooth. So clean. A little watery, but no mind.Overall, this is excellent. A little different yet classic. Well done. You should certainly give this a try.
Dark golden with rich maltiness.  Crisp effervescence and some spicyliness from hops.  Finishes crisp and refreshing.  Exceptionally drinkable.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

This is great because it really is a well brewed and tasty fest brew but because its SN it is freaking everywhere. There are others I like better but none Ive drank more. Copper with a tan head. Earthy with light malt sweetness. Nice crisp and lightly dry finish. Very clean. Good fest bier.

Clear, deep gold appearance with a large white head and good lacing. Aroma of honey wheat bread and caramel malts. Flavor of subtle, spicy hops prevent the sweetness from becoming too controlling while creamy, toasted malts add depth in the aftertaste. Medium bodied, nicely carbonated mouthfeel. Tasty nuances elevate this fest beer above the pack.
Newly inspired Oktoberfest directly taken from German brewers. I have a cold right now, so I cant really taste it.

Yum. Nice clean reddish lager pour. Very balanced flavour profile that reveals expert malt and hop blending as the glass warms. So often it seems that brewers pump this style out to cash in on a season, but this was a terrific offering. Too bad this will be a one off, but very interested in seeing what next years collaboration will bring.

Bottle to snifter. Nose is moderately sweet with caramel and a hint of buttery diacetyl noted. Perfectly clear, light orange in color. large white head, tight bubbles. Taste is moderately bitter up front, with a firm but smooth bitterness, malt then comes in and shows signs of bread, toast, and crackers. Malt flavor is very rich, without being cloying. As far as the beer, goes, this is pretty damn good. As far as an Oktoberfest, I think it is way to bitter, and actually reminds me more of an altbier. I like this.
Very mild smell little malty...taste is malty sweet malt...touch of spiciness in there...smooth but straightforward...better with time
Clear golden orange body with a short white head. Sweet biscuity malt aroma. Grainy malt bread flavor, slightly earthy with a lightly hoppy finish.

Caramel brown in color... Aroma of biscuity malts, light hops... Flavor is biscuity and malty, but still light and crisp... Easy to drink

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle. Served in a mug, the beer pours a mostly clear dark gold color with about an inch off-white head that stuck around a while. Theres a small amount of lacing. Aroma is nice, it smells like grainy/bready malt, toffee and some earthiness. The taste is pretty much just like the aroma, with the addition of some herbal hops. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy, smooth and easy to drink. Overall I liked this, its a solid brew and worth trying at least once.

Pours a clear light gold with a 1 finger head of foam and has good lacing.

Smells slightly sweet, some grain, light bread, a bit earthy. A do get a mild hoppy note or 2.

Nice malt character in the taste. Some sweet notes, some bread, any grain is very much on the light side. Very mild bitterness in the finish.

Easy drinking cuz it has a great mouthfeel.

This is delicious.
Way solid beer...beer of the month at work...not malt heavy...crushed my bottle in 3 sips...great upgrade on this one this year...yummy!

Clear golden pour with spicy malt on the nose. Taste - classic Oktoberfest flavored of toasted biscuity malt, spicy and earthy. Liberally hopped for balance. Solid, well done Marzen. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Wholefoods. Crisp lagery and European hop aroma. Solid honey malt taste with a crisp bitter finish with hints of hay. Boozy too. Solid lager.

Bottle. Clear golden with white head. Malty aroma with hints of corn & grain. Rich malty palate, full body, hops balance. Finish lingers and sweetness is slightly cloying but it definitely reminds me of true German Helles or brew served up at the famous festival. I need more of this.

2015 bottles drunk September/October 2015.Clear, moderately carbonated chestnut-copper body has a very small, thin, light beige head that fizzles to cover and then nothing.Very fruity nose (cherries, apricots, nectarines) also shows a good deal of sourdough, dry hay and light caramel. No alcohol and its clean, but perhaps not a very good strength of aroma, all told.Sweetness emerges immediately (caramel, cookie dough) and then becomes balanced by moderate hop bitterness and eventually succumbs to the carbonation and wateriness. Along the way there are some interesting sourdough and fruit notes. Fairly balanced and with enough maltiness for the style but the texture is just really sad here. Its overcarbonated and what is there is rather fizzy and loose. As well, theres very little richness of malt (suppleness) that one would expect from a top notch Oktoberfest. Still, its enjoyable enough, if rather disappointing for all of this "Collaboration with a small German brewery" business.
Medium golden color with lots of carbonation. Beautifully topped with white head. Clean hoppy aroma. Crisp fall taste. Some appley aftertaste lingers.

Bottle pours burnt orange with a white head that turns into a small film. Malty, toffee aroma with a slight hint of earthiness. Good carbonation. Get the slightest hint of acetaldehyde, but pretty solid otherwise.
Pours a dark golden color with an orange tinge and thin white head. Malt aroma with flavor that hints at pumpkin and malt.

12 oz bottle purchased at Metcalf Discount Liquor (135th Street) in Overland Park, Kansas. The pour is a clear golden orange with an egg white one inch head that falls with a coating of lace. There is a ton of fine carbonation bubbles rising to the surface. The aroma is clean caramel malt, nice grassiness and a bit of toast towards the back. The taste is the malt; husky, softly sweet, cracked cereal grain, and a faint herbal mineral towards the back. Interesting malt expression, not really like any malt profile I can remember having. The palate is medium bodied, with softer natural carbonation and the malty, herbal grass finish. Nice one.

Ill start my 800th rating by saying that Ive had Sierra Nevadas Oktoberfest on tap at their Oktoberfest in Chico and this new version for 2015 is completely different. The old Oktoberfest was a fairly dark lager that, while a good beer, was really not in the style of Oktoberfest/Marzen. This new version is so to style that they should be serving this in Germany in a few days when Oktoberfest kicks off! Crystal clear medium golden yellow with a perfect persistent white head. The aromas are dead on German lager with a toasted malt nose. The taste follows suit with a perfect bready malt flavor and creamy texture with a touch of light vanilla sugar sweetness. This is balanced by a solid earthy bitterness that tastes like proper Noble hops rather than American hops (not sure if thats true or not) and is a bit more assertive than you would generally find in a German version, but it works beautifully here. The bitterness and delicious lager flavor stay behind after every sip and makes you crave more each time. Sierra Nevada obviously went out of their way to partner with a German Brewery (Brauhaus Riegele) to create this Oktoberfest and the result is nothing short of spectacular. This is now one of my (if not the) favorite Oktoberfest lagers Ive ever had and I cant wait to have more of it on tap in a few weeks at Sierra Nevadas Oktoberfest in Chico!!  Im kind of bummed that its going to change again next year, but if the next version is anything like this one, I cant wait to try it. Happy Oktoberfest (in 2 days) everyone! Prost!!

Lightly sweet, no hops apparent. Could use a bit more malt flavor.

Draft at the Mills River brewery. Pours clear amber with a fizzy white head. Tastes like sweet bready malt, nutty, some corn, and light spice. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like bready nutty malt and sweet corn.

Tap at NC brewery. Pours clear gold. Aroma is bready and caramel malts, lager yeast esters, faint pear, and faint spice. Flavor is dry and clean with a touch of caramel sweetness and soft fruit notes. Light/medium body.

12 oz bottle from a six pack. Purchased from "Habits" cig and beer store in S.Salem OR
$8.29 for the pack.
Clear bright copper coloured beer with a nice sized thick creamy off white head.
Fine aromas..mainly caramel and hay like malts..touch of grassy hop in the back.
Taste is clear and straightforward..maybe a bit too much hopping, but its drowned by tasty malt.
Very nice effervescent mouth feel..drinkable in extreme.
 Good Oktoberfest

Pours a pale copper with a thin white head. Aroma is earthy hops, bread malts, and caramel. Flavor is sweet bread, caramel, with earthy and spicy hops. Has a light bitterness. Body is fairly hefty. Decent, not entirely memorable.

This was poured into a mug, sorry, I dont own any steins or siedels. This was the closest correct glassware I had.
The appearance was a soft somewhat hazy yellow/orange color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated at a nice gentle pace. A foamy milky glaze sticks around the glass nicely.
The smell starts off with some toasty earthy nuttiness. A light sweet grassiness rides in as it warms along with some caramel malt.
The taste follows the smell with a sticky sweetness lingering along a moderately crisp to sweet nutty aftertaste. The finish is quick and semi-sweet.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with a nice sessionability about it. Carbonation rides pretty low allowing the stickiness of the sweet malts to shine.
Overall, I liked it for me, and would definitely like this one next to some soft pretzels and spicy mustard. Im ready for Autumn!

Pours a light amber color. Aromas are baked bread, lightly toasted grains, a touch of brown sugar and earthy sweet potatoes. Flavours are great... Mimic aromas. Lightly sweet and toasty. Balanced and delicious. Maybe the best Oktoberfest Ive ever had.
Tastes like Bavaria in a good way. Lots of vanilla woody and bublegum butterscotch.

Had over at the crab cake a torium.. Deep Amber .. Really impressive foam .. A bit dry, light caramel and bread .. mild fruit in the back .. . Really nice Oktoberfest.. . . Thumbs up! Time for a stranger under the table!

Bottle from Market Basket.
Crystal clear deep golden color with a decent sized long lasting bubbly white head. Great bready pilsner malt nose with lots of floral peppery spice hop aromas. Has a rich melanoid on the nose but the high hop smell makes me think more of a Pilsener than Marzen. The flavor feels better. Rich sweet melanoidins against a bready pilsner base with some lightly peppery hop flavor. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation. One of the better American attempts at a Marzen.

Pours a light amber color with a thick white head. Sweet malt, caramel, biscuit and light earthy hop aroma. Sweet malt, caramel, toffee, earthy hop, biscuit, nutty, toast and floral flavors. Medium light body and average carbonation. Sweet malt and biscuit finish.

Clear gold pour witha large off white head and good retention. Good lacing. Taste is a good mix of American and German Oktoberfest beers. Great lager taste with lighter malt and caramel flavors. 6.0 ABV is well hidden.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2015 Bottle. Clear orange with a short white head. Aroma is malty and fruity with dominant notes of mandarin orange, honey, hay, nuts, glazed pastries. Medium-light bodied, sweet with moderate bitterness, its fruity and juicy and somewhat slimy, malt has some savoriness but the carbonation seems weak and brash. As it warms the nose turns more like fruit candy and less like malted barley. No major flaws, its an easy quaffer, but the orange soda quality doesnt measure up to authentic maltiness of Bavarian Festbier.

Aroma caramel, bread, cereal, butterscotch, 
Appearance golden, clear, white foam, 
Taste light sweetness, 
Palate light body, medium body, soft carbonation, 
Overall not my style of beer but that being said it is a good oktoberfest that I would suggest to a friend

New Beer Distributors, NYC bottle ($2): pours amber with white head. Aroma is caramel malt with some light hops. Taste is pretty standard for an oktoberfest, which came as a bit of a surprise given that is from SN. Very clean. Clean hops. Not bad, but forgetable.
Pretty good for style, with nice barley profile. Pours brownish orange with OK head. Crisp and clean finish. Bottle.
12 oz. bottle. Poured a clear copper with a thin white top that dissipated quickly. Taste of caramel, malty with a slight hop bitter finish. Lively carbonation, light-medium body. Very well balanced

Crystal clear yellow amber with a small but dense white head that leaves modest lace. Aromas of toasted malt and a bit of brown sugar. Flavor is similar, spearheaded by the muted sweetness of the toasted malts, accompanied by sticky caramel and a touch of breadiness. Medium body, sticky mouthfeel, lively carbonation and a crisp fall finish.

Pours a clear golden color with a white head that quickly goes away. Aroma is of malts, hops, flowers, and rye. Heavier palate, not too carbonated. Flavors are of malts, wheat, grain, earthiness, and hops. Leaves a slightly sweeter malt and wheat finish.
Three 12 oz bottles poured into a Maßkrug. One fine looking glass of beer. Tastes bready and malty, with a hint of Sierra Nevadas characteristic hop bitterness. Very good for the style.
Clear gold in color with lots of visual carbonation. Thin white head that disappears fast. Sweet malt aroma. Medium body with the malt dominating. Finishes sweet and filling.

Draft at Fado. Clear dark golden yellow with a couple fingers of soft off-white foam. Expectedly malt forward but also balanced with more hops than usual. Toasted honey whole wheat. Burnt vanilla caramels. Some Tangelos. Apricot pits. Bitter florals. Violets. Sage. Thyme. Medium body. Missing the German yeast flavors I had hoped for with this new collaboration. Hops dry things out but ultimately brings makes it feel a bit too harsh for the style.
Bottle at Evernote in Redwood City, CA. Nice caramel, malt backbone with a mild earth hoppiness. Very drinkable.

On tap. Served a clear dark golden color with a white head. and some lacing. Aroma of malt, caramel bit of grain and hops. Taste of malt sweetness touch of citrus and grain. Mild bitterness and a dry finish. Moderate body, smooth, and flavorful, but not the rich character usually found in an Oktoberfest style beer.

I don't know what is wrong with this I can't put my finger on it. I feel like it's not ment to be for fall.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Malty, grassy, grainy, very bready aroma. Beautifully clear, lasting thin head, little to no lacing. Grainy malt dominates the flavor profile with just a hint of spicy herbal hop character. VERY clean brew, perfect marzen character, perfectly balanced. Silky smooth mouthfeel, right amount of bittering. Overall a pleasure to drink and makes me wish I were in a bier garden pounding this by the liter! Wish I had bought more!

12oz bottle to mini dimple. Deep golden yellow. Bready biscuit malt flavor. Definitely some interesting herbal hop character. Certainly leans to a traditional German style, rather than an American malt bomb.

Bottle:
Pours clear, deep gold with a foamy, off-white head.
Sweet grain, caramel aroma.
Taste is creamy, soft caramel malt .
Very solid....very malty and rich.
Sweet and easy drinking....very nice herbal hoping.
Good stuff.

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - 12 oz bottle. Sparkling, medium copper pour, quickly diminishing light off-white head. Pleasant light spicy aroma, hints of nutmeg, a trace of date fruitiness. Flavor is pleasantly sweet with some light molasses, a hint of date fruitiness, just a hint of nutmeg-like spiciness. Mouthfeel has a nice crispness to it,

Bottle. Deep amber gold body with a foamy slightly yellow tinted head. Nose of strong yeasty dough and apples. There is also some leather and floral character. Flavors are up front with leather and a hint of salt. I also got some apple core and then cheap tobacco in the finish. Hints of black tea and caramel are also present. Well made and quite pleasant. A slightly sharp highly carbonated mouth feel. Unique and interesting for a normally tame style.

Gold, thin off white head. Weak clean malt nose. Bitter hops dominate. But as the beer warms, the malt really comes to the forefront. Still a bitter aftertaste, but very balanced. Sold carbonation. Could be a great session beer.

12iz bottle that pours a golden clear yellowish orange with light white head. Aroma is typical marzen/Oktoberfest style with nice malt aroma and mild hops. The flavor is off the chart the smooth blend of malts and hops that make up this beer is fabulous. It is so smooth yet the flavors are bouncing all over your tongue. My new favorite Oktoberfest.

Bottle via oakbluff. Vibrant copper in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of clean toasty malt and a bit of orange marmalade. Flavors are of more toasted malt, mild citrus, and light minerals. Light bodied and super clean. Quite enjoyable.

Bottle from Fred Meyer. Medium copper in color. Nose is sweet and malty. A little yeastiness in there as well. Rich maltiness up front with a bit of sweetness. Very full flavored. Good bready malts with a light grassy hop character. Sweet backbone. Really tasty.
12oz bottle to cervoise. Pours clear amber with white soapy head. Aroma of pale and german malts, corn, and sweet grains. Taste is the same with sweet bread and cereal. Not my favorite marzen beer.

bottle. clear copper body with a thin greyish mostly white head. aroma is light candy with a bit of a white grape scent. cereal notes are there in the nose too. malt forward with a bit too much bitterness in a light medicinal way. malt flavors are candy cereal and honey. bit less hop and id be happier, but it aint bad.

Bottle from Albertsons. Rich, deep golden body with small, soft cream colored head. Buttery malt on the aroma, as expected. Taste follows with lots of sweet malt, and a thick, chewy consistency. Finishes a bit flat, all else though, this is an exemplary marzen. Prost!

12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear golden hue with a medium white head. A nice nose of sweet dusty malts,toffee. Sugary almost very sweet malts, dusty leaves, some stick sweet almost maple syrup vibe. Vibrant smooth flavors. Nice.

Bottle - this falls more on the Wiesn end of the Oktoberfest spectrum, so not quite as toasty (or perhaps as robust) as some folks tend to expect - this is more along the lines of a Heller Bock flavor and palate wise than most would expect from a Marzen - okay, now that that is out of the way, I have to say I really like this - rich Munich malts in the nose, some honey, some floral hop character, bread dough - soft texture - light to medium body - clean but rich sweetness, very clean throughout - balancing floral hops and a mild mineral note round things out - quite good.
Bottle Clear orange with afull and lasting full white head. Light malts slighty toasted. Thin dry and clean with a little noble hop bite. A good example of a style I dont care for in general

A partnership between Sierra Nevada and a long-standing German brewer? Yes. Please. Look, Oktoberfests are some lovely beers. This one is particularly sexy. Clear, light orange liquid and a fluffy head. Bread aromas abound, but theres some grassy-ish hop character, too. Flavor is mostly on the malty-sweet side, but theres a little hop bitterness. Finish is clean. According to the six packs packaging, Oktoberfest if a one-time release for bottled distribution. If thats true, its a damn shame. Still, Im lucky to have gotten to purchase it at least once.
Malt aroma with light grain. Clear light orange color with a small white head. Lightly bitter throughout with hints of sweetness.

12 oz. bottle. Reddish orange pour with a full off white head. The head fades into whispy bubbles on top. Soapy lacing. Aroma of spicy and herbal hops. Mild caramel and toffee sweetness. Flavor is hoppy, with sweet malt notes. Full bodied, above average carbonation. One of the best Marzen Ive ever had.

If there was ever a beer that proves that sometimes a single serving isnt enough to rate from this is it, at least for me. I was shocked at first the hopping of this beer, way more hoppy than any bottle Munich marzen. After reading an article about this being the best ofest in the world, I was mildly offended when I discovered this tastes virtually nothing like the Munich exports. No chewy toffee malts, really hoppy. But as I dont rate to style, I was not gonna really ding it, but I guess I couldnt help but be annoyed as I gave it a 3.6 and hit submit. Then I had a 3rd, and a 4th, and those spicy hops kept kicking up against the lightly sweet malts, and I thought, damn this is growing on me. I deleted the rating. The next day I killed off the rest of the six pack and savored every drop. True marzen or not, this is a beautiful fucking beer that I could drink all year long.

From a bottle. Pots a medium Amber and makes a white head with some lacing. Smells of brewer's sugar, caramel, and malt. Tastes of light hops, roasted barley, toffee. Yum. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear golden orange with a robust white head. Aroma is spicy hops and malt. Taste is sweet malt, buttered biscuits, maple syrup and a bit of sharp hoppiness at the swallow that balances well with the malt sweetness. Very good!

Clear pale copper. Big white foamy head. Nice malt aromas. Rich sweet malt flavors of toffee, caramel, honey, followed by a little hop bitterness. Light amount of spicing. Medium body. Highly drinkable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Nose stiff thin malt, sweet and lightly grainy, touch plummy/grapey, which I do associate with Riegele and may just be inventing here. Some white grape aromatics and sunny bright pils character. Pour ultra clear deep, dark golden with a soapy off-white head. In the mouth, a bit coating/chalky with pleasant grainy bread crusts, that berry/grape is also here, no doubt, with the wine fumes in the aftertaste; nutty and toasty character more for the aftertaste after the bright but mild citrus subsides, but the toast is king in its domain. Malty medium body, medium sweetness just slightly overpowers bitterness. Really like the different direction taken here, fundamentally enlivening without simply dumping on the newest aroma hop.  I definitely want to reach for a second, but accumulation would prevent me from going through any more than that. Nice seasonal.
Poured a very pretty color with a nice head. In the mouth there are way more hops then I would like for the style.
Bottle. Pours a golden amber color. Aroma and taste are toffee, caramel, and some honey.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a honey golden color with a moderate sized fluffy beige head hat leaves a clinging lace. Aroma is a faint toasted maltiness. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor with caramel notes. A wonderful spicy herbal hop midtaste. Nicely balanced and quite flavorful. A bit hoppier than Bavarian Oktoberfests, but still a great brew.
On draft. Clear golden copper with one finger head. Caramel and sweet malt aroma. Caramel, a little nutty. Pretty good.

The beer pours clear copper with a beige head. The aroma has toasted malt, smooth caramel, and a touch of earthy hops. The flavor starts with the aroma notes, but has more nuttiness. Really great oktoberfest.

Clear golden-copper body, large off-white head, and spotty lacing. Toast, toffee, honey-biscuits, light florals, and a touch of grass. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation, a clean, balanced sweetness, light bitterness, satiating.
Light malt aroma. An autumn orange clear body with only a slight film for a head. Has a firm malt taste with a mild bitter bite to counter this. Has a clean finish and is refreshing.

For some reason, it makes me mad that Sierra Nevada makes an Oktoberfest and then I try this motherfucker and its good so now Im just straight pissed off about basically everything. This is a pale amber beer which is perfectly clear and topped w/ a foamy but small white head. Its aroma is kinda mild, lightly toasty and grainy but this really has a nice malt character overall. Its dry--you see, Sierra Nevada understands that malty styles do not have to be sweet--and there is a solid heft of toasted malt and some pleasant grain husk notes. This is medium to full bodied w/ brisk carbonation and a lingering earthy bitterness in the finish. Honestly, I am pretty much at the point where I have to say Sierra Nevadas lagers are more to my liking than their ales, which seems almost blasphemous, but, hey, I call it like I see it.

12oz bottle. Clear pale copper. Nice aromas of caramel malts. Heres where it gets really good. Rich sweet malt flavors of toffee, caramel, honey, followed by a Noble hop bitterness that sneaks right into the richness of this beer to balance out this style. Superior body. Clean finish, yum, yum.

A steady pour into my Sierra Nevada IPA glass produces a two finger thick, pale amber tinged, tan colored head. the beer is a pale amber / copper color that shows a brilliantly clear, deep gold tinged metallic copper hue when held up to the light. The aroma has a spiciness to it, a sweet maltiness, as well as a solid, whole grain complexity to it. Soft notes of currants, spicy hop notes, lots of caramelized malt complexity, red grain cracker aromas, sun-baked grain husks, spicy red grain notes, and as the beer warms up a touch, soft, floral, citrus notes.

Spicy, bitter, but balanced with a solid malt character, this beer is actually very balanced in my first sip with a bit more hop character than I was expecting from the aroma. Peppery, spicy hop notes and a carbonic bit balance out the caramelized, and whole grain malt flavors that add just a touch of malt sweetness. There is a touch of fruit character here, perhaps more from the hop character than the malt, though the latter supports it; the fruit notes lean towards currants perhaps, with maybe just a suggestion of floral citrus character. The beer has a lively effervescence to it, and this matches nicely the light, but still chewy, medium-light body that this beer achieves; the body of this beer is just about perfect for this style of beer.

I was actually expecting this to be pretty good, but this has still pleasantly surprised me more than I expected. Quite well executed, and it really has a nice, fresh, malt / hop balance to it that makes this quite drinkable. This is one of the better Oktoberfest beers that I have ever had.

They were bottling this beer when we toured the Sierra Nevada Brewery last month, so it seems this was really fresh. Crisp, firm malts and a nice slightly bitter finish. Stays fairly sweet throughout, though, for the most part. I enjoyed it...

12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, bottled on 6/30/2015. Pours fairly crystal clear golden amber color with a 2 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of honey, toast, biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of bready malt and earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of honey, toast, biscuit, light nuttiness, hebral, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Light earthy/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of honey, toast, biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice robustness, balance, and compelxity of bready malt and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Extremely clean on lager flavors with zero estery yeast notes present. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and fairly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Oktoberfest style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of bready malt and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. This version was paler in color and malt character than the 2014 batch; but was equally as impressive. A very enjoyable offering.
Aroma is fruit, berries and malts. The flavor is fruit, berries, malts and a mildly bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours deep gold/light copper, off-white head. Good retention/lace. Aroma is grainy, toast, spicy/grassy hops. Taste is lightly bitter, fruity, grassy, lightly soapy, spicy hop. Palate is crisp, clean, grainy finish. Wow this is good for a Märzen!

bottle. clear gold with under a small white head. a lighter colored beer for this style. aroma is quite hoppy also for style. i get lots of grassy/floral hops in here. flavor has nice grainy pale malt flavors with a floral bitterness. quite sessionable at 6%. i prefer a little more malty chewiness in this particular style, however, this is perfectly acceptable as are many variations.
Sampled at AOT Wilmington. Opaque brown I believe it was. Aroma of malt, caramel, nut, hop, toffee and bread. Full bodied and lots of flavor. Good effort but I think theres too much going on here.

Havent rated a beer in a while. I love Oktoberfests and this one really hits the mark! Much needed addition to the regular 6-pack group. Easily one of my favorites. Sour dough and very light balanced rich toasty caramel, super clean. Full flavored but not sticky with plenty of lively carbonation. Hot damn this is good!
Pours a yellow, golden, light copper company lor with a nice white head. Aroma of toasted malt, light hop spice. Taste is grassy, toasted malt, grain with a spice/black pepper hop finish. Good stuff.

Pours a clear coppery color with off-white head. Caramel malt, toffee, and wheat tones on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied. Finishes with a nice toffee malt note. Better than the previous year.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2015 2nd try. Had it back in August and did not enjoy - seemed a little skunky. This bottle is quite tasty however. Pours light amber with minimal off-white foam. Doesnt look like much. Smells very subdued malt and toasted bread. Flavor is mostly bready malt with a slight caramel sweetness on the finish thats very, very nice. Fairly clean finish with slight lingering sweet.

Original Review:
Thin, light yellow color - looks unimpressive. Aroma has a dankness from a hop style of which Im not a huge fan. Same comes through in the flavor, which while uninteresting, is fairly smooth. Pretty disappointing overall.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2015 Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass.

Appearance: a 1" white head settles quickly with a bit of lacing. Color is golden and clear with moderate streaming carbonation.

Aroma: toasted barley malt and some hop presence

Mouthfeel: medium bodied and a bit creamy with an easy dry finish.

Flavor: toasted barley malt (not overly sweet), biscuit, and a definite lingering hop bitterness in the middle and finish.

Overall: well done and pleasant. another winner from Sierra Nevada.
Good brew - plenty of malt, caramel and grain in a fresh, very drinkable beer.
Its ok. Average in about every sense of the word. Its a little bitter in the finish. Goes down fairly well for 6%. Ok.

Bottle; poured an orange amber with an average off white head. Aroma of biscuits, caramel, fruit and touch of toffee. A nice, somewhat aggressive for the style. Caramel and biscuit, mostly dry, maybe some bittersweet elements. Full body with some grassy/earthy hops in the finish. Good for the style
Nose is toasty bread, faint orange marmalade, honey. Flavor is initially mild grassy, fading to sweet doughy, finishing toasty/bread crust. Simple but controlled, clean, refined.

Aroma of toasted malts and buttered biscuits, with a hint of burnt caramel and cashew. Flavors of earth, caramel, and aged toffee. Finish is fall like and crisp. Although nobody wants to think of the quickly approaching fall season. A brew like this softens the blow and almost makes me wish for my youth and dive straight into the most epic pile of leaves. To be a kid..

Pour is a clear tan with a large white head. Aroma is a nice dry biscuit and bready malt. Flavor is another dose of a stellar dry dark bread and cracker like malt. This is one of the best marzen/o-fest beers Ive had in a while. Those malts are so clean and full of toasted grain flavor. Liquid bread here.

Bottle. Poured clear light copper color with an average to large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a copper color with a nice off white tight frothy head that lingers. Aroma is nutty caramel malt and light spice and even softer hop presence. Taste is nutty spiced caramel malts with a crisp soft bitterness. Palate is thin crisp fizzy and slightly dry. Very good!

The beer pours clear golden copper with a beige soapy head. The aroma has toasty malt, toasted walnuts, fresh baked dough, smooth caramel, lager roundedness and a hint of spicy / earthy hops. It has a medium crisp body with a good amount of carbonation. The flavor starts with the aroma notes, but has more nuttiness, crackers, caramel and some herbal notes. The finish is clean and dry. Really great oktoberfest.

Had much higher expectations for this, even got a sixer blind. I've come to the conclusion there are European Octoberfest/Marzën and then there are American Octoberfest/Marzën...and I definitely and vastly prefer the bolder, richer, more flavorful "American" version...of which this is not. Meh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an orange / amber color with a foamy off white head. Notes of caramel, toasted grains, fresh air, and sweet breads. As far as oktoberfests go this is nice as it is missing that husky sort of awkward bitterness.
Bottled, bright orange color with some foam, octo corn and caramel hop aroma, flavor is husky, grains, some grass, caramel

355ml bottle. First of the season. Clear deep golden colorw, nice foamy white head. Appearance is perfect. The aroma is an herbal, grassy hop nose, breadcrust. It is really fruit-forward and stronger in alcohol tasting than the average Oktoberfest beer. Also a fuller creamier mouthfeel. Plenty of ssweet bready malt and herbs in the flavor. Im suprised that adding Riegele to the mix didnt set this one apart. It is good, fresh, and drinkable but not the peak of the style, but then again the 3 Riegele helles beers I had were pretty much average when fresh.

On tap @ Sierra Nevada. Clear golden pour with white foam. Malty, toasty, bready beer. Kind of grainy, perhaps. Floral and grassy hops. Slight pie crust, some cracker, and fruity esters. Really nice malt profile and some bitter hops. A slight huskiness, unfortunately which is kind of off-putting.
Bottle. nose is grassy malt. Leafy flavors. balanced. Fact, Fall is coming and will go. The sudden cold front and this beer indicate that Fall is coming. Suck it summer heat and humidity!

Bottle. Pours a clear, bright gold with a small, fizzy head. A little clumpy lacing. Aroma is heavy on toasted grains and biscuit dough., with a little earth/grass hanging out in the back. Flavor starts as bitter orange peel, then backs off to a sweeter candied fruit, with the toasted cereal and biscuit character from the aroma coming through toward the end. Finishes with a little hop bite. Very light body. Anyone with a taste for the darker, thicker, more heavily spiced beers that are generally sold as Oktoberfests or marzens in the US might be put off by the (admittedly more authentic) toasted lager profile of this one.

Clear bright golden amber. White dissipating. head. Toasty. A little sweet caramel. Balanced with some earthy hops. Mild bitterness. Just a bit of spiciness. Excellent balance. Just enough body to not be watery. Great drinkability. Good for an often bland style.

Pours copper-orange with a one finger white head with decent lacing. Aroma is of toasted bready malts, caramel, sweet malts, earthy and spicy hops, and some grassy hops. Taste is toasted bread, caramel, sweet malts, earthy/ grassy hops, light spicy hops, light toffee, and some light pine. Has a medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and slightly bitter, yet still pretty sweet, slightly dry, long finish. Overall, a fantastic marzen that may be that best Oktoberfest bier ever brewed.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2016 Bottle into lager glass; clear amber-golden color with off-white head. Aroma notes of bread, caramel malt sweetness, some earthiness and faint spice. Taste adds toast, grain, slight fruitiness and grass hop bitterness. Light-medium body, moderate carbonation, crisp, creamy with clean roast grass finish. Tasty, lighter feeling oktoberfest compared to most U.S. brewery releases.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Clear copper, thin creamy off-white head, decent retention. Aroma of toasted malt and herbal hops. The taste is toasted malt, caramel, floral and herbal hops. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, well balanced, highly drinkable. Simple, well executed, damn good beer.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2015 Bottle-Pours bright deep orange hue with a nice 1/2 inch white fluffy head that remains along the rim of the glass and some sparse lacing. Nose is earthy, lovely toasted grains, spicy hops, slight mineral aspect, just smells perfect for the style. Flavors are lovely toasted and caramel malt husks, spicy hops, and a really nice yeast character. This is truely fantastic stuff. I have yet to have a Marzen with this kind of character and cleanliness. Love the cereal, bready notes on the nose. SN hits it out of the park once again!

8/9/15. 12oz bottle, sixer, from Publix. Crystal clear light orange pour with a big khaki head, great lacing. Cant complain, looks nice. I even busted out a dimpled mug for this one. Nice aroma takes me back to when I used to like these sorts of toasty lagers more... nice biscuity malt aspect, grassy, toasted nuts, pale and pils malts. Yum. The flavor disappoints, sadly. There is a nice light toasted aspect but the beer is quite sweet, loads of caramel, and an almost acidic bite that straddles between green apple and lemon juice for me. Finishes with a nice dry toasty aspect that makes me sad about the sweet middle. I wish this was a tad more chuggable and less sweet. Otherwise not bad.

On draft at the ALS event. Wow. Is it weird I thought this was one of the best beers I had at the festival? It pours a golden orange color with a white head. The aroma is nice and toasted with light hints of mandarin orange and noble, earthy hops. The flavor is the same. Very bready with a strong toasted finish. The noble, earthy hops come through sronger with only light hints of orange and florals. The fresh, toasted malt quality is a stunner. So drinkable. Im so glad this one was put into sixers. Cant wait to pick up more.

Bottle. Beautiful golden amber body. Aroma is sweet mix of malt and caramel. Flavor is slightly sweet caramel, light toffee some bitterness in the back ground. The mouthfeel starts creamy but ends nice and dry. Well done!

Aroma: bread, grass, 
Appearance: clear gold, off-white head
Taste: light sweetness, lightly bitter,

Bottle. Dark amber with a medium, foamy white head. Aroma is big caramel, toasted malt, dark bready notes and grass. taste is sweet malt, toasted grains, caramel, floral hops, dark bread and grassy hops. Body is medium and chewy with a dense, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more caramel, dark bread, toasted malt, grassy hops and floral notes.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2015 12 oz bottle- Pours clear golden with a nice large white head that slowly reduces. Aroma is grassy hops, sweet light caramel malt, toasted grains, all subtle. The taste is at first caramel malt, then a generic beery flavor comes in, which i wish wasnt there actually, then the hops present themselves, spicy and grassy,. Body is thinner than expected and carbonation is on the high side. Not bad, easy drinking and enjoyable.

Dark golden color with a diminishing creamy white head. Pale to toasted malt aromas. A touch of buttery biscuit. Crisp and clean lager feel. Lightly bitter. Hints of sweetness in the front. Dry finish and linger. A clean light amber lager.

Bottle from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. Pours gold with a creamy white head. Aroma of mildly spicy bread. Med body or nearly. Flavor is mildly spicy bready. Finishes fairly dry and somewhat bitter. Better than many Ive had.
12 ounce bottle. Amber orange in color. Muted nose. Light sweet caramel malt body. Tasty.

Oktober seems to come earlier and earlier every year. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma is grainy malt with floral hops and herbal yeast. Flavor is caramel malt with some grain with some bready notes. Finishes with crisp floral hops and herbal yeast. I like that Sierra Nevada collaborated with a German brewery to create this beer. Great idea and made this beer more appealing to me.

12oz bottle, from Dutchs. Bottled 7/09/15. Clear orange color. Nice finger of white head. Leaves good ropes of lace initially, kind of just loose later though. Medium-plus body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter to moderate carbonation. Nice fullness to the feel. Very mildly dry finish. Great toasty, kind of bready, mild spicy, mild peppery aroma. Nice bit of oktoberfest lagery funk to it. Kind of biscuity. Moderate sweet taste, lighter but satisfying bit of bitterness. Very solid, satisfying oktoberfest. Up to the standard I expect for Sierra Nevada.

Bottle from Lisais chester Market. Clear copper with ring and a little lace. Milf toasted toffee/caramel and grassy hops clean. Medium sweet caramel grainy fresh with medium minerally and hay bitterness. Some lingering sweetness slick but not sticky. Medium light body. Very good.
Bottle from a sixer given to me by my brother. Clear gold pour with a medium white head. Nose consists of malt, sweetness and crisp hop. Sweet malt and caramel flavor with a crisp lager finish.

12 oz bottle from a six pack bought at the supermarket. Bottled about two weeks ago. Pours new penny copper with a thick off-white pillowy head with excellent retention; laces a little. Aroma is lightly toasty, generic beer, apple. Taste is grainy, light toast, lightly sweet. Watery, slightly thin body. Eh.

Bottle at local Smiths. FINALLY SN releases a dedicated Oktoberfest apart from their Fall Pack, and an actual German style festbrau lager at that. I must admit, I was rather taken with their amber ale Oktoberfest rendition last year, but this takes me back to the Rheinland Pfalz, where the stronger amber lagers rule this time of year. As such, this is a little more bitter, a little lighter in color, and just about right at 6% ABV vs the typical ~5.5% amber ales that typically get passed of as an Oktoberfest over here. What can I say? Bring on the 1L mugs, the Oompah bands in lederhosen, and the strong armed frauleins in traditional garb (or not). Looks like this is a one time release, so Ill be laying in a few cases of this for the fall season

text: Bottle. Light copper orange hue, with a decrepit white head. Malty, breads, some slight caramel and malty sweetness as well in the aroma, some leaves and earth in there as well. Flavor is not sweet, but some caramel, light toffee, bread and leafy earthy jobs at the end. Lighter bodied. Just ok, but better than some other U.S. takes on the style.

Pours clear amber/orange with about a finger of frothy head. Aromas of caramel and nuts. Malty flavors up front with caramel notes and toasted nuts. Medium bodied with a touch of sweetness and a dose of hops in the finish. Another enjoyable offering from Sierra Nevada.

Pale amber. Nose of lightly fruity toasted malt, faint noble hops, and a touch of diacetyl. Flavor is light grainy toasted malt, orange, mild bitter hops and a splash of minerals in the finish. Alcohol somewhat noticeable. Overall, decent American version.
From the sixer. Reddish gold pour with a thick off white head. Malty Cara sweetness, spicy hop aroma. Smooth big body malt, bready with spicy hop bite. Damn nice marzen.

An easy drinking October fest beer. Not my favorite style but I liked this one.
